strengths: Clean module decomposition: audit-loader.ts resolves data sources transparently, validate.ts provides schema-level verification with typed ValidationResult<T>, types.ts serves as single source of truth -- each module has one job and they compose well.

CI pipeline is a genuine verification gate: ci.yml runs typecheck, lint, prettier, tests, and build in sequence on every push/PR -- automated quality enforcement that catches regressions before they ship.

CLAUDE.md is a compound learning artifact that actually works: 129 lines of specific, actionable rules (Common Mistakes, Design System constants, Context Reference Library with task-to-file mapping) -- accumulated project knowledge that prevents recurring errors.
weaknesses: Validation coverage gap: validateSynthesisReport checks top-level structure but does NOT validate individual agent entries in agents[] -- malformed agent scores would pass silently.
No runtime verification of audit data integrity on dashboard: results/page.tsx trusts getAllAuditSummaries output completely with no per-file error handling.
2 prettier warnings remain unresolved despite PostToolUse hooks and CI checks -- gap in automated enforcement system.

strengths: Dashboard now wired to real audit data via getAllAuditSummaries() -- the last-mile gap from iteration 1 is closed. Users see actual results, not demo placeholders.
Dual data resolution strategy in audit-loader.ts (LOCAL_DIR for dev, COMMITTED_DIR for prod) solves the data-location problem elegantly for both local and Vercel deployment.
Error boundaries, runtime validation via parseSynthesisReport(), and graceful null handling mean the dashboard degrades gracefully instead of crashing.
weaknesses: Time to first visual value is still too high: new users must install plugin, run /bc:audit (which takes minutes), then visit boardclaude.com or run local dashboard. No zero-config demo mode.
boardclaude.com shows only self-audit data -- visitors get no interactive value without installing the CLI. Broken discovery-to-adoption funnel.
Install command 'claude plugin add boardclaude' is aspirational -- no public Claude Code plugin registry exists. Users following README instructions hit a wall immediately.
critical_issues: Plugin install path does not work for external users -- no public plugin registry and no documented manual install fallback.

strengths: Closed-loop self-improvement proven across 3 iterations (68.4->80.7->83.5) with the audit-fix-validate-re-audit pipeline actively using Agent Teams -- genuinely novel recursive AI evaluating itself using its own architecture.

Dashboard wired end-to-end with runtime validation: audit-loader.ts calls parseSynthesisReport before data enters the type system, error boundaries catch failures, Vercel auto-deploy extends feedback loop to production.
Model routing is well-justified: Opus for complex evaluators with effort=max, Sonnet for structured tasks -- genuine model-capability alignment producing measurably divergent evaluations.
weaknesses: Extended thinking configured via effort levels but no empirical measurement of how thinking depth affects evaluation quality -- no A/B comparison making adaptive thinking claim architectural rather than evidence-backed.
1M token context window underutilized: no cross-iteration context loading. Each iteration starts fresh rather than accumulating context progressively.
Agent debate/disagreement is emergent but not structured: divergent opinions discovered post-hoc by synthesis rather than through deliberate multi-round debate.

strengths: TypeScript strict mode exemplary: strict:true, noUncheckedIndexedAccess, noImplicitReturns all enabled. Only one any in entire codebase (RadarChart.tsx:55, properly eslint-disabled).
Error boundary coverage now comprehensive: app/error.tsx (global), app/results/error.tsx (route-level), loading.tsx with spinner, not-found.tsx -- significant improvement from iteration 1.
Server Components used correctly: results pages are async server components. 'use client' only where interactivity needed. No useEffect for data fetching. Textbook Next.js App Router patterns.
weaknesses: ListSection in AgentCard.tsx:106 uses index as key for strengths/weaknesses lists -- CLAUDE.md forbids this pattern.
ScoreProgression.tsx uses useEffect for prefers-reduced-motion instead of framer-motion's useReducedMotion hook (used in AgentCard) -- creates hydration flash inconsistency.
No error.tsx at [auditId] route segment -- errors bubble to global error.tsx losing route context.

strengths: README is excellent -- clear description, quickstart with copy-pasteable commands, architecture diagram, command table, custom panel YAML example, and audit output. Value clear within 30 seconds.
AgentCard demonstrates strong a11y: aria-label, aria-hidden on decorative SVGs, role='list' on score bars, useReducedMotion hook, and focus-visible ring patterns.
Community infrastructure solid: CONTRIBUTING.md with setup steps, CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md (Contributor Covenant 2.1), issue templates for bugs and features, conventional commit history.
weaknesses: No root-level LICENSE file -- README claims MIT but no actual LICENSE file exists. Legal gap for contributors and corporate adopters.
No CHANGELOG.md to track versioned changes despite referencing v0.1.0/v0.2.0 in docs.
No screenshots, GIFs, or visual assets in README. Dashboard is the visual centerpiece but README is entirely text.
critical_issues: Missing root-level LICENSE file -- blocking for any organization with legal review processes.

strengths: Excellent narrative arc -- README nails problem/solution/impact. One-sentence description immediately understandable to non-developers. Landing page reinforces with 'Your AI Jury' tagline.
Strong community potential through configurable YAML panels and templates -- natural sharing/community loop.
Production deployment is real -- boardclaude.com live on Vercel with auto-deploy, error boundaries, well-structured plugin manifest.
weaknesses: Internationalization remains the biggest gap: strings extracted to messages.ts but no i18n library wired, date formatting hardcodes 'en-US', Inter font only loads 'latin' subset.
Error page strings hardcoded in error.tsx rather than pulled from messages.ts, breaking extraction pattern.
Accessibility gaps: no skip-to-content link, inconsistent focus indicators, no aria-labels on interactive elements beyond SVG.

top_strengths: End-to-end data pipeline now complete: audit agents -> validated JSON -> audit-loader.ts with parseSynthesisReport -> server components -> live dashboard at boardclaude.com with error boundaries -- cited by all 6 agents
Proven 3-iteration self-improvement loop (68.4 -> 80.7 -> 83.5) using recursive Agent Teams evaluation -- genuinely novel AI architecture cited by Boris, Thariq, Cat
TypeScript strictness exemplary (noUncheckedIndexedAccess, noImplicitReturns) with comprehensive error boundary hierarchy and textbook Server Component patterns -- cited by Lydia, Boris
top_weaknesses: Plugin install path ('claude plugin add') non-functional for external users with no documented manual fallback -- adoption blocker cited by Cat (critical issue)
Missing LICENSE file despite MIT claim in README -- legal blocker for community adoption cited by Ado (critical issue)
Internationalization stuck at string extraction without actual i18n library, locale switching, or RTL support -- cited by Jason, Ado

agent_a.position: STRONG_PASS (85.45) -- recursive self-improvement loop is genuinely novel AI architecture that crosses the frontier from clever to genuine AI system

agent_b.position: PASS (79.15) -- adoption funnel is broken at the install step; most potential users have no working path to first value

divergent_opinions.analysis: Thariq evaluates the AI architecture which is genuinely innovative. Cat evaluates the user journey which has real gaps. Both are correct: the system is technically impressive but practically inaccessible to new users.

agent_a.position: STRONG_PASS (89.3) -- README, CONTRIBUTING.md, issue templates, and a11y patterns are exemplary community infrastructure

agent_b.position: Critical issue: missing LICENSE file undermines all community work -- can't call it community-ready without a legal foundation

divergent_opinions.analysis: Ado's own evaluation captures a genuine tension: the community documentation is excellent but the missing LICENSE file is a fundamental gap that could have been caught by the project's own quality gates.

action_items.action: Add MIT LICENSE file at repository root
action_items.impact: Removes legal blocker for community adoption -- critical issue

action_items.action: Add manual install path to README (git clone + manual setup) alongside aspirational 'claude plugin add'
action_items.impact: Unblocks adoption for all external users -- critical issue
Achieves 100% format compliance, proves automated enforcement works end-to-end

action_items.action: Add agent-level validation inside validateSynthesisReport for agents[] array entries
action_items.impact: Closes biggest validation gap in the feedback loop

action_items.action: Add error.tsx at app/results/[auditId]/ route segment, fix index-as-key in AgentCard ListSection, use useReducedMotion consistently
action_items.impact: Completes error boundary hierarchy, removes anti-patterns

action_items.action: Add screenshot/GIF of dashboard to README
action_items.impact: Visual proof of the product -- highest-impact README improvement

action_items.action: Wire next-intl or equivalent i18n library to messages.ts with locale detection
action_items.impact: Moves i18n from extraction to actual locale support

improvements: Thariq: +3.6 (81.85 -> 85.45) -- proven 3-iteration loop, end-to-end validated pipeline to production
Cat: +3.5 (75.65 -> 79.15) -- dashboard data wiring closes last-mile gap, error boundaries add trust
Jason: +2.7 (77.15 -> 79.85) -- production deployment live, improved narrative, error handling
Boris: +2.5 (82.0 -> 84.5) -- real data pipeline proven, improved CI validation
Ado: +1.25 (88.05 -> 89.3) -- error boundaries improve UX, continued strong documentation
